qas.question: To what study did Mimamsa give rise?
What did the Mimamsa school think that language was meant to describe?
What school thought that language was supposed to be widened to describe and develop?
What parts of the Vedas did the Mimamsa school emphasize?
What sections of the Vedas did the Verdanta school favor?

plausible_answers.text: the study of philology and the philosophy of language

qas.question: What did Mimamsakas and Vedantins agree on?
What did Mimamsakas believe was the purpose of an orderly life?
What school was foundational to the Mimamsa school?
Which part of the Vedas did both the Vedanta and the Mimamsa schools emphasize?

context: Mīmāṃsā gave rise to <b5_0>the study of <a0_0>philology<a0_0/> and the philosophy of language<b5_0/>. While their deep analysis of language and linguistics influenced other schools, <b6_0>their views<b6_0/> were not shared by others. Mīmāṃsākas considered the purpose and power of language was to clearly prescribe the <a1_0>proper, correct and right<a1_0/>. In contrast, <a2_0>Vedantins<a2_0/> extended the scope and value of language as a tool to also describe, develop and derive. Mīmāṃsākas considered orderly, law-driven, procedural life as central purpose and noblest necessity of dharma and society, and <b7_0>divine (theistic) sustenance<b7_0/> means to that end. The Mimamsa school was influential and foundational to <b8_0>the Vedanta school<b8_0/>, with the difference that Mīmāṃsā school developed and emphasized karmakāṇḍa (that part of the śruti which relates to ceremonial acts and sacrificial rites, <b9_0>the <a3_0>early parts<b9_0/><a3_0/> of the Vedas), while the Vedanta school developed and emphasized jñānakāṇḍa (that portion of the Vedas which relates to knowledge of monism, the <a4_0>latter parts<a4_0/> of the Vedas).
